MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Teachers' Early Retirement Scheme.

Qst.Quest: the sum of money, if any, which was budgeted to pay the early retirement component of the teachers' proposals under the Programme for Competitiveness and Work; if not, the reason this sum was not expended; the reason this sum was not carried into their 1997 Education budget, thus allowing more teachers to avail of the offer in view of the fact that this sum was a committed part of the National Agreement, with an implementation date of 1996.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The scheme for the early retirement of teachers, negotiated under the Programme for Competitiveness and Work, was agreed with the INTO in autumn 1996 and with the other teachers' unions in spring 1997. Following agreement with the INTO, the scheme was introduced in the case of primary teachers in October 1996. The number of applications received for early retirement in 1996 was 64 which was well within the provision made.

In 1997, when the scheme was extended to teachers generally, the scheme provided for up to 400 retirements. Following notification of the scheme to schools in June 1997, applications were received from 185 teachers.

As this number was below the annual quota provided for, and at the request of the teacher unions, my Department invited further applications for early retirement in October 1997. Sixty-three further applications have been received and these are being processed.
The cost of all retirements arising in 1997 under the scheme for the early retirement of teachers are being met from Vote 45 — Increases in Remuneration and Pensions.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Education in Disadvangtaged Areas.

Qst.Quest: if he has satisfied himself that the educational system provides an adequate preparation at primary level in disadvantaged areas for young people who hope to achieve employment in the future; and if he will make a statement on the matter.
the proposals, if any, he has to improve the education system at primary and secondary level in disadvantaged areas; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 146 and 147 together.

MainHeading.P: I assure the Deputy I am acutely aware of the importance of early educational intervention to support children in disadvantaged areas. While significant advances have been made in this area in recent years, I have no doubt that much still needs to be done.

At present, a comprehensive range of special support services are targeted at children in disadvantaged areas. At primary level, these include the early start pre-school programme; the disadvantaged areas scheme; the breaking the cycle pilot programme; the home-school-community liaison scheme; and the teaching counsellor scheme. Expenditure on these schemes in 1997 amounted to in excess of £17 million.

Yesterday's budget announced a major innovation in the tax treatment of donations to disadvantaged schools. This initiative is aimed at significantly improving the capacity of disadvantaged schools to secure funding thus putting them on a level playing pitch with schools for whom, traditionally, fund raising has not posed a problem. The details of this scheme will be set out in the forthcoming Finance Bill.

At post-primary level, measures include curricular reforms such as the junior certificate elementary programmes and alternative leaving certificate programmes; second chance education and training through the provision of Youthreach for qualified early school leavers; and the provision of additional educational services to second level schools to cater for the needs of disadvantaged pupils, such as the allocation of disadvantaged, remedial, guidance, home-school links and resource posts.

Most recently, under the mid-term review of EU funding, I have obtained significant funding for projects which will focus on children in the eight to 15 age range who are at risk of early school leaving or who are already outside the mainstream school system. New initiatives in urban and rural areas of disadvantage will be supported over the next two years to establish models of effective practice. The initiatives will involve parterships of local agencies, with schools collaborating with voluntary and statutory bodies in the delivery of preventative and support services for young people in the age range.
I am also reviewing provision across the special needs area, including the area of educational disadvantage, to ensure that all resources which become available will be utilised to maximum effect.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has for the improvement of facilities in the smaller rural schools throughout the country; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: Under a new devolved grant scheme introduced this year each national school is paid a basic grant of £2,000, plus £9 per pupil, to carry out improvement work to building, grounds, services and furnishing. Schools are not required to communicate with my Department in respect of works being undertaken.

In devising the new scheme, consideration was given to a payment based solely on enrolments but this was rejected on the grounds that it would be unfair to small and special schools. The basic grant of £2,000 was introduced to overcome this difficulty.
It is also open to schools to apply for grant-aid for works outside the scope of the devolved grant scheme. These applications are considered in the context of available capital resources.

Qst.Quest: if he will improve or expand the free school transport system; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The school transport scheme currently caters for 160,000 pupils daily, including 9,000 pupils with special needs, at a cost to the Exchequer of £40 million per year. The operation of this service involves 2,358 vehicles, and covers 34 million miles annually.

As the Deputy will be aware, the school transport review committee has recently completed an extensive review of the school transport system. The committee's report was reviewed by my colleague, Deputy O'Dea, Minister of State, in September 1997, and is currently being examined in my Department.

It is intended to publish the report early in 1998 and to ensure that it receives the widest possible dissemination. My aim is to stimulate an extensive debate on the contents of the report before making final decisions on any future changes to the school transport scheme. I want to make it quite clear that I will not take any decisions until I have reflected on the debate.

Qst.Quest: if he will review the criteria in respect of the establishment of regional colleges with the objective of locating one of these colleges in County Kildare; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The steering committee on the Future Development of Higher Education was asked to examine “within the overall national context . the needs for higher education on a regional basis .”. Following its examination of Dublin and the surrounding counties, the committee recommended Blanchardstown as the appropriate location for the establishment of a new regional technical college to serve the north, north-west and north-east Dublin region as well as growth areas in Meath and Kildare.

A planning group is currently undertaking the development of a strategic plan for a college in Blanchardstown which includes, inter alia, industry links, support services and research and consultancy. The courses will focus on the needs and the human resource requirements of leading edge high technology industries and on languages, business, science and engineering fields.
The needs of County Kildare are also catered for in the development plans for Carlow and Tallaght Regional Technical Colleges.

Qst.Quest: his views on an allocation of only £70,000 for 1998 for the National Adult Literacy Agency; if he will review this situation with a view to increasing this amount; if he will inform Deputy Farrelly of the current number of Irish adults who have very low literacy levels; the number of people providing classes in this regard for the vocational education committees throughout the country; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The total allocation by my Department to the National Adult Literacy Agency in 1997 amounted to £196,000. The provision for adult literacy in 1998 has been increased by £2 million over the 1997 Estimates but the financial allocations to adult education agencies have not yet been finalised for 1998.

The recent OECD report on adult literacy in Ireland gives cause for concern. The report revealed that an estimated 500,000 Irish adults have low levels of literacy. My Department will be considering the issues raised in this report.
There are approximately 110 adult literacy schemes operated by the vocational education committees throughout the country.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: whether the Commission on the Future Funding of Education chaired by a person (details supplied) has completed its work; the number of meetings which it has held; and when he will receive the report in this regard.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The technical working group on the funding of second level schools was established in November 1996 to recommend a framework for the recurrent funding, excluding teachers' salaries, of second level schools.

MainHeading.P: The technical working group comprises a number of technical experts and its report, which will be published, will be submitted to a steering group, the members of which have been nominated by relevant second level interests. The group's work on some aspects of the funding system is nearing completion. However, work on other aspects of this complex area is ongoing and will continue for some time.
